desirability2 0.0.0.9000
  • Reference

Desirability functions for in-line computations

inline_desirability.Rd

Desirability functions map some input to a [0, 1] scale where zero is unacceptable and one is most desirable. The mapping depends on the situation. d_max() increases desirability with the input while d_min() does the opposite.

Currently, only the desirability functions defined by Derringer and Suich (1980) are implemented.

d_max(x, low, high, scale = 1, missing = 1)

Arguments

x

A vector of data to compute the desirability function
low, high

Single numeric values that define the active ranges of desirability.
scale

A single numeric value to rescale the desirability function.
missing

A single numeric value on [0, 1] (or NA_real_) that defines how missing values in x are mapped to the desirability score.

Value

A numeric vector on [0, 1] where larger values are more desirable.

References

Derringer, G. and Suich, R. (1980), Simultaneous Optimization of Several Response Variables. Journal of Quality Technology, 12, 214-219.

See also

d_max_select()

Examples

library(dplyr)

#> 
#> Attaching package: ‘dplyr’
#> The following objects are masked from ‘package:stats’:
#> 
#>     filter, lag
#> The following objects are masked from ‘package:base’:
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union
library(ggplot2)

set.seed(1)
dat <- tibble(x = sort(runif(10)), y = sort(runif(10)))
d_max(dat$x, 0.1, 0.75)

#>  [1] 0.0000000 0.1564337 0.2546287 0.4186522 0.7274667 0.8140216 0.8627658
#>  [8] 1.0000000 1.0000000 1.0000000

dat %>%
  mutate(d_x = d_max(x, 0.1, 0.75))

#> # A tibble: 10 × 3
#>         x     y   d_x
#>     <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#>  1 0.0618 0.177 0    
#>  2 0.202  0.206 0.156
#>  3 0.266  0.380 0.255
#>  4 0.372  0.384 0.419
#>  5 0.573  0.498 0.727
#>  6 0.629  0.687 0.814
#>  7 0.661  0.718 0.863
#>  8 0.898  0.770 1    
#>  9 0.908  0.777 1    
#> 10 0.945  0.992 1    

set.seed(2)
tibble(z = sort(runif(100))) %>%
  mutate(
    no_scale = d_max(z, 0.1, 0.75),
    easier   = d_max(z, 0.1, 0.75, scale = 1/2)
  ) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = z)) +
  geom_point(aes(y = no_scale)) +
  geom_line(aes(y = no_scale), alpha = .5) +
  geom_point(aes(y = easier), col = "blue") +
  geom_line(aes(y = easier), col = "blue", alpha = .5) +
  lims(x = 0:1, y = 0:1) +
  coord_fixed() +
  ylab("Desirability")
